Of the individual epistles, Ep. i. 13 Was evidently contemporaneous with the publication of Odes i.—iii. Of the others all those whose date can be assigned with any certainty, appear to belong to B.c. 20. But it is probable that Horace was engaged with this style of composition more or less at various times during the five years Rc. 24—20‚ that is to say from the fortieth to the forty-fifth year of his age.

The conclusions to which we are thus brought are practically the same as those maintained by Franke, and supported by the weighty approval of Lachmann. Bentley in his preface assigned a slightly later date, and needlessly limited the time of composition to two years (Bc 20—19); Ritter holding that Odes i—iii. were published in B.C. 19 is compelled to postpone the publication of the first Book of the Epistles to ac. 18.

The time of the publication of the Second Book 'and of the Ars poetica is open to more doubt. But the dates of composition, which' on the whole seem most probable, are for Ep. ii. 1 about 13.C. 13, for Ep. ii. 2 about 13.C. 19, and for the Ars Poetica, B.C. 20 or 19. The reasons which lead us to these conclusions will be found in the Introductions to the several Epistles. If they are sound, Book ΙΙ.
